update.description:
This pull request adds a tutorial for the force/torque sensor. It gives an example world, and describes the behavior of all the SDF parameters.

[preview of the tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=force_torque_sensor&branch=force_torque_sensor_tutorial)
update.title: Force torque sensor tutorial

content.raw: this needs to be updated once [gazebo pull request 2653](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2653/force-torque-sensor-visualization-using/diff) is merged
content.html: this needs to be updated once gazebo pull request 2653 is merged

content.raw:
As an example, this is what I added on the gif:

~~~
        <visual name="visual_cylinder">
          <pose>0 0 -0.75 0 0 0</pose>
          <geometry>
            <cylinder>
              <radius>0.0100000</radius>
              <length>1.5</length>
            </cylinder>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
~~~
content.html:
As an example, this is what I added on the gif:

        <visual name="visual_cylinder">
          <pose>0 0 -0.75 0 0 0</pose>
          <geometry>
            <cylinder>
              <radius>0.0100000</radius>
              <length>1.5</length>
            </cylinder>
          </geometry>
        </visual>

content.raw:
While reviewing this tutorial I noticed that the force / torque sensor visualization wasn't working. So I made a [gazebo pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2653/force-torque-sensor-visualization-using/diff) fixing it.

I also made a little gif to demonstrate the visual, using this tutorial. Feel free to use the gif here if you want:

https://github.com/chapulina/gzgif/blob/master/force_torque_sensor.gif
content.html:
While reviewing this tutorial I noticed that the force / torque sensor visualization wasn't working. So I made a gazebo pull request fixing it.

I also made a little gif to demonstrate the visual, using this tutorial. Feel free to use the gif here if you want:

https://github.com/chapulina/gzgif/blob/master/force_torque_sensor.gif

content.raw: Indeed. See https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/130/position-part-of-force_torque-sensor-pose for a strictly related problem on several real world models.
content.html: Indeed. See https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/130/position-part-of-force_torque-sensor-pose for a strictly related problem on several real world models.

content.html: This is a cool tip!

content.html: Wow that's one confusing parameter.

content.html: Oops, I mean parent joint

content.html: We could add "with respect to the parent link frame"

content.html: It could make it more intuitive to also have a cylinder visual connecting the joint origin to the sphere.

content.raw: Suggestion: Add "issue" in front of #2209. Many users are not familiar with our issue tracker, so they might not associate the number to that.
content.html: Suggestion: Add "issue" in front of #2209. Many users are not familiar with our issue tracker, so they might not associate the number to that.

content.raw: I see a lot of interesting physics parameters in this world. It might be interesting to mention them, not in great detail, but at least to acknowledge them and let people know that things might not work the same way with default parameters. Maybe just comments in the world file would suffice.
content.html: I see a lot of interesting physics parameters in this world. It might be interesting to mention them, not in great detail, but at least to acknowledge them and let people know that things might not work the same way with default parameters. Maybe just comments in the world file would suffice.

content.raw: Why is this `massLink2` here, but `mass` above? Actually, there is only one link in this model.
content.html: Why is this massLink2 here, but mass above? Actually, there is only one link in this model.

content.raw: The image would be a great place to show these variables too. Like `theta` and where it is counted from...
content.html: The image would be a great place to show these variables too. Like theta and where it is counted from...

content.raw: It could help to explain in the text above what the variables here refer to. For example "Because the sphere is positioned 1.5 m away (radius `r` equals 1.5 m) ..."
content.html: It could help to explain in the text above what the variables here refer to. For example "Because the sphere is positioned 1.5 m away (radius r equals 1.5 m) ..."

content.raw: It might also help being specific in which direction the force should be applied to achieve the configuration which is discussed here
content.html: It might also help being specific in which direction the force should be applied to achieve the configuration which is discussed here

content.raw:
Detail about modeling sensor on real robots is perfect for a tutorial! Rephrasing your comments to make sure I understand:

Modeling a force/torque sensor as being part of a revolute link makes sense if the distance from the real world sensor to the joint origin is small enough that the error doesn't matter, such as:

![force_torque_on_revolute.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/RMMxjX/images/2579464437-force_torque_on_revolute.png)

Otherwise a rigid body should be divided into two links with a fixed joint at the location of the force/torque sensor

![force_torque_on_fixed.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/RMMxjX/images/29110018-force_torque_on_fixed.png)
content.html:
Detail about modeling sensor on real robots is perfect for a tutorial! Rephrasing your comments to make sure I understand:

Modeling a force/torque sensor as being part of a revolute link makes sense if the distance from the real world sensor to the joint origin is small enough that the error doesn't matter, such as:

Otherwise a rigid body should be divided into two links with a fixed joint at the location of the force/torque sensor

content.raw: Thanks for the feedback. To be honest I misunderstood the documentation in the SDF specification. After reading it again I see that it's actually very clear. I'll remove the sentence I wrote and copy from the SDF spec.
content.html: Thanks for the feedback. To be honest I misunderstood the documentation in the SDF specification. After reading it again I see that it's actually very clear. I'll remove the sentence I wrote and copy from the SDF spec.
